description.narrative: Preparation of Grenada's Second National Communication to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC)
The project aims at enabling Grenada to prepare and to report its Second National Communication to the Conference of the Parties (CoP) of the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC)
independent political entity

The Second national Communication report posted on the UNFCCC website. The GHG and V&A reports available in the Ministry of economic affairs. Frequency of public messages and media articles addressing climate change and its impacts. Climate change impacts addressed in disaster and development plans..

comment.narrative: Grenada's First National Communication, technology needs assessment and vulnerability reports are currently available at the Ministry of Economic Affairs. There is a cadre of trained persons available to conduct the GHG and V&A assessments.

title.narrative: Integrated Climate Change Adaptation Strategies- Grenada

description.narrative: % of CBOs/NGOs receiving training % of target population (CBOs/NGOs) implementing CBA measures from the Programme, disaggregated by gender % of targeted population participating in adaptation and risk awareness activities, disaggregated by gender % of CCCAF accessed Number of website visits % of stakeholders represented at discussions and exchanges Number of lessons learned and good practices on CCA measures generated and disseminated Number of contributions in online discussion fora

comment.narrative: There are no ongoing community-based adaptation (CBA) measures . Awareness of adaptation and risk are limited to technical professionals and has little translation at the community level, with no active awareness initiatives. Capacities of grassroots organizations with respect to project development and implementation is weak, but being gradually addressed through GEF SGP. Caribbean Planning for Adaptation to Climate Change (CPACC) implemented 1997-2001 http://www.caricom.org/jsp/projects/macc%20project/cpacc.jsp . Adaptation Learning Mechanism (ALM) is a global repository for mapping good practices, sharing knowledge and building networks on CC adaptation http://www.adaptationlearning.net/

- 70% of target population participating in adaptation and risk awareness activities - 100% of CCCAF disbursed - 5,000 website visits - 75% of stakeholders represented - 10 lessons learned and good practices disseminated - 300 contributions in online discussion fora - 4 PSC meetings convened - 90% delivery

- 86% of target population participating in adaptation and risk awareness activities - 60% of CCCAF disbursed - 12,000 website visits (facebook platform included) - 90% of stakeholders represented - 10 lessons learned and good practices disseminated - 535 contributions in online discussion fora - 1 PSC meeting convened - 75% delivery

- 90% of target population participating in adaptation and risk awareness activities - 80% of CCCAF disbursed - 20,000 website visits (facebook platform included) - 95% of stakeholders represented - 15 lessons learned and good practices disseminated - 300 contributions in online discussion fora - 4 PSC meetings convened - 90% delivery

- 95% of target population participating in adaptation and risk awareness activities - 80% of CCCAF disbursed - 32,000 website visits (facebook platform included) - 95% of stakeholders represented - 15 lessons learned and good practices disseminated - 250 contributions in online discussion fora - 1 PSC meetings convened - 85% delivery

description.narrative: Implementing a “Ridge to Reef” approach to protecting biodiversity and ecosystem functions within and around protected areas in Grenada

title.narrative: Implementing a “Ridge to Reef” Approach to Protecting Biodiversity and Ecosystem functions within and around Protected Areas in Grenada
R2R PSC meeting 1 and Inception Workshop 19032015

description.narrative: Implementing a “Ridge to Reef” approach to protecting biodiversity and ecosystem functions within and around protected areas in Grenada
independent political entity

OUTCOME 1 Institutional framework for management effectiveness in and around PAs Regulatory and legal framework for management effectiveness in and around PAs Expansion of protected areas system Measurable Threat Reduction: - Forest cover - Direct Carbon benefits - Indirect Carbon benefits - Mangrove, seagrass bed and coral reef areas Management of expanded PA network institutionalized PA network infrastructure and services Community involvement in PA management through conservation and sustainable use of natural resources Benefits/profitability from conservation/ sustainable-use resource-based livelihood opportunities
OUTCOME 2 Planning and management framework for SLM/INRM Community participation in SFM. Direct carbon benefits through avoided deforestation; forest enrichment; and planting in the Beausejour watershed. Turbidity Levels/ sediment buildup at two MPAs downstream of Beausejour Pesticide and fertilizer levels at two MPAs downstream of Beausejour. Application of gender and community-sensitive SLM and SFM practices in 6 communities (Beausejour, Happy Hill, Granville Vale, New Hampshire, Annandale and Vendome) Impact of Soil erosion/stability on household incomes of famers within the Beausejour watershed Education and awareness levels

comment.narrative:
OUTCOME 1 - No formal National Parks Advisory Council - Forestry Division administers 8 TPAs under suboptimal conditions - Fisheries Division administers 3 MPAs. - Forestry policy does not include INRM. - Fisheries division does not use INRM in its administration of MPAs - 3,711 ha of bio-diverse landscapes/seascapes formally recognized and facing multiple threats - 8 TPAs managed under suboptimal conditions and 5 mini TPAs with no management mechanism. - TPAs cover 1,931 ha. - 3 MPAs management suboptimal conditions - MPAs cover 1,780 ha - Continuous deforestation threatens 10,012 hectares - 81,652.5 tC (Direct - 322,158.3 tC (Indirect) - Continuous destruction of 231 Ha of mangrove, 1301 Ha of seagrass and 5095 Ha of reef areas - No PA System Business Plan exists - No coral Reef resilience program (protocol) in place - No systematic SFM program in place
- No staff trained in planning accounting, bio principal monitoring, enforcement, fire management and co-management - Inconsistent infrastructure and facilities and services across TPAs and MPAs. - 0 communities adjacent to MPAs engaged in PA co-management - 0 communities adjacent to TPAs engaged on PA co-management - No systematic collaboration for INRM linked to livelihood opportunities - Minimal benefits from resources based livelihoods
OUTCOME 2 - No LUP regulations limiting agriculture and housing. - National Forestry Policy does not consider C sequestration. - No intersectoral body or committee in place for implementing a watershed management plan using INRM approaches. - Stakeholders not engaged in community-based rule-making with respect to applying INRM practices. - No systematic monitoring for water quality/quantity, sediment and pollution impacts - No involvement of local stakeholders in initiatives to review and update the National Forest Policy (NFP) to consider carbon sequestration. - 9,613tC sequestration by 3337.3 ha. of private forest - 4,320tC seques

1. Construction and deployment of 5 FADS on the Western side of Grenada 2. Establishment of coral nurseries at approved locations 3. Implementation of Terrestrial Protected Areas education and awareness campaigns

1. Due to sudden changes within the administration of the Fisheries Division, the program was put on hold. 2. During the period of July to November, coral nurseries were established in Grand Anse. 14 coral tables were constructed with the assistance of 4 fishermen volunteers selected. 3. An education consultant has conducted the following activities: production of outreach materials and five PSAs for radio and TV; school visits; and production of 4 articles for the local media.

1. Enhancement of the coral reef restoration and propagation initiative through procurement of a research vessel 2. Completion of a management plan for the Mt. St. Catherine protected area 3. Enhancement of natural resources management at Morne Gazo 4. Improvement of public awareness about biodiversity conservation and natural resources management

1. The construction of the research vessel was completed in March 2017. It has been used for the coral reef restoration and propagation initiative along with other conservation activities 2. The consultant firm contracted to develop the management plan canceled the contract. Another consultant firm has been engaged and the management plan is expected to be completed in 2018. 3. An interpretation center was constructed and handed over to the government in 2017. It is expected to function as a hub for conservation activities in the area. 4. 2 summer camps were successfully conducted for school children, improving their understanding about the importance of biodiversity conservation and natural resources management.

title.narrative: Support to Referendum on Constitutional Reform in Grenad

description.narrative: To support the constitutional review process in civic education sensitising the public to the reforms being proposed, and a precursor to the public referendum which is needed to endorse any constitutional amendments.

It is expected to contribute to significant improvements in the country’s governance, in particular by strengthening public understanding of the constitution, and issues around human rights, gender equality and public accountability.
Environment - policy, planning and administration

- Iterative drafting process undertaken, producing revisions following advice - Civic education programme designed and implemented - At least 2 civic education forums targeted at youth and women - Ballots printed - Voter education undertaken - Public Referendum undertaken

comment.narrative: - Draft Bills initiated by CRAC and under review - Some public consultations undertaken by CRAC - NAM reviewed electoral laws and identified deficiencies - Limited public awareness and knowledge of the constitutional reform process - Limited public knowledge on proposed amendments to the constitution
- At least 10 civil society organisations delivering civic education covering all of Grenada. - 100% of poll clerks trained. - Voter education strategy implemented in all of Grenada.

9 civil society organisations were awarded small grants in order to conduct civic education around the proposed amendments to the constitutions. A lessons learnt workshop is planned for the 9th December, where CSOs will deliberate around the impact and effectiveness of the workshops.
The creation of an ICT platform that will be used by the Parliamentary Elections Office for a more efficient, transparent and rapid communication of referendum results. In supporting of the rollout of an ICT base platform in order to improve the efficiency of the tallying of votes for the Grenada Referendum. End User training was conducted over a five (5) week period. All Representatives from participating polling divisions have the capacity to utilize the software and they were able to manage the activities on referendum day. Additionally, IT staff in the office of the Supervisor of Elections have the capacity to manage the system from a technical and administrative aspects.
UNDP support to the voter education strategy through the creation of voter education video to support public education as well as the production of a booklet and flyers around the seven amendment bills and the flyers.

title.narrative: Climate Resilient Agriculture for Integrated Landscape

description.narrative: To operationalize integrated agroecosystem management through mainstreaming biodiversity conservation in the production landscape and increasing resilience of agricultural system
To operationalize integrated agroecosystem management through mainstreaming biodiversity conservation in the production landscape and increasing resilience of agricultural system
independent political entity
Energy - power generation
